headline: Micron, Trade Desk, Western Digital: 2025's Big Stock Movers
summary: ↘️ Trade Desk (TTD): The advertising-technology company is poised to be the S&P 500's biggest loser in 2025. Shares have slid around two-thirds so far, their worst year on record. The company missed revenue estimates in February, and the stock was downgraded by analysts in August.

headline: How Western Digital Became the S&P 500’s Best Stock in 2025—and Why Trade Desk Was the Worst
summary: Artificial intelligence was the foremost theme dominating 2025.  Western Digital  dominated the benchmark index this year.  Western Digital is best known as a major supplier of traditional hard disk drives, used for high-capacity data storage.

headline: AI Chips Today - AI Infrastructure Surge Driving Market Growth
summary: The AI data center industry is rapidly expanding from niche buildouts into a highly capital-intensive sector, driven by the need for advanced infrastructure to support macro model training and inference. This shift is characterized by competition for GPUs, energy capacity, cooling systems, and long-term power contracts, as these requirements push AI infrastructure spending to new heights. With an investment prediction reaching up to $5.2 trillion by 2030, according to McKinsey & Co., public...

headline: 2026 Is a Make-or-Break Year for the AI Trade
summary: The “AI trade”—investing in companies linked to the artificial-intelligence data-center buildout—is about to enter its fourth year, and that brings questions of durability to the fore.  Yes, 2026 is a make-or-break year, and in the end, power supply may be what applies the brakes.  For now, demand for data center hardware from the likes of  Nvidia  and  Micron Technology  remains high, and that will continue at least through the first half of 2026.

headline: China's CXMT eyes $4.2 billion Shanghai listing to fund DRAM expansion
summary: China's leading maker of DRAM chips, ChangXin Memory Technologies (CXMT) Corp, said on Tuesday it plans to ​raise 29.5 billion yuan ($4.22 billion) through an initial public offering of 10.6 ‌billion shares in Shanghai.  The company, which directly challenged South Korean and U.S. rivals by unveiling its latest DDR5 ‌DRAM chips last month, will use the listing proceeds to upgrade production lines and technologies, it said in a prospectus on Tuesday.  Founded with state backing in 2016, CXMT ⁠spearheads China's efforts to gain ‌a foothold in the global DRAM market, dominated by South Korea's Samsung Electronics and SK Hynix, and U.S.-based Micron Technology.
